RADIO & TV NEWS
By J. Don Schlaerth
National Study Lauds
Work of UB Station
U A COMMUNITY-minded sta-
tion.” That’s the way
WBFO-FM (88.7 me.), the State
University of Buffalo student-
operated radio outlet, is de-
| scribed in a recently released
major research study on edu¬
cational radio in America.
The report, financed by the
Ford Foundation, singled out
the local station as “one of the
few to do research among the
minority groups in the com¬
munity.” It points to five major
productions “which display its
(WBFO’s) interest in reaching
out and embracing its total com¬
munity.”
The program series named
were Discriminating on Discrim¬
ination, the Buffalo Urban
League Report, To Be a Negro,
Focus on Foods and Nation With¬
in a Nation, a study of the
Iroquois Indians in WNY.
* * *
WILLIAM H. SIEMERING,
associate co-ordinator of student
activities and faculty manager
for the campus radio station,
was praised for visiting “the
I low-income fruit-belt of Buffalo
to conduct a porch-to-porch sur¬
vey” for the Focus on Foods
series produced in co-operation
with the American Dairy Coun
jcil.
The station also was com pi \
mented for its University Con¬
vocation lectures, two days of
broadcasts of Buffalo’s Model
City Conference and “its experi¬
mentation with new aural con¬
cepts as its radiovision.” In one
experiment, UB professors and
students discussed on the air
colorful original paintings in the
station's program guide which
circulates 5500 monthly copies.
WBFO broadcasts highlights of
the Senate Subcommittee on
; Communications hearing on edu¬
cational radio at 9 this evening.

BUFFALO RACEWAY broad¬
casts. including a description of
the feature race, will be earned
on a five-station network again,
this season, starting Monday, j
WKBW’s Jim Fagan hosts the
program to be carried at 10:30
PM on WEBR, WDOE, Dunkirk,
WJTN, Jamestown, WBTA, Bata¬
via, and WROC, Rochester.
A national radio test helps
mark WKBW’s recognition of
National Radio Month next week.
The Quiz will last a half-hour
and test a listener’s knowledge
of 11 musical styles.
Among the station disc spin¬
ners who took the exam, Jeff)
Kaye, a musician, scored 87. j
Morning man Stan Roberts
joined this writer with a low
mark of 73.
